author: justafish25
body:
I invested my life savings in December through February with the largest amount in early February.  Had a lot of dumb bull shit like CGC (41 average), DIS (141 average), XOM (58 average), Fang (74 average).  Had a bunch of other stuff that had done better.  

Completed my V shape recovery today.  I sold everything on the bounce in late March to around 255.  I was down 45%. Since then I have been short term momentum trading options and am now up 1% total.  It’s not much, but I’m happy to be back in the green.

author: Q_The_Underscored
body:
Anyone looking for a v shaped recovery isn't considering the public sector, which has become a huge percentage of the economy.

How much taxes do unprofitable companies pay?  Little to none.  Can they carry their loses forward?  Yes.  When would federal/state/local governments see a return to normal tax revenue if coronavirus was magically cured in 2020?  Several years, best case scenario.  

2019 tax revenue was 3.46T, it's going to be much lower for a long time.  Government spending will not be cut.  Deficits will balloon, the debt will be monetized, gold will soar.

author: moronavirus__
body:
> Businesses are have already been moving away from China the past couple of years. 

[Tell it to popeye's which just opened in Shanghai and is planning on hundreds of stores in China](https://supchina.com/2020/05/15/long-lines-for-grand-opening-of-popeyes-shanghai-which-ran-out-of-food/)

Ok but you need to realize that China isn't just a cheap slave labor outpost anymore. author: kingoffortlauderdale
body:
>The **Waffle House Index** is an informal [metric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performance_indicator) named after the [Waffle House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waffle_House) restaurant chain and is used by the [Federal Emergency Management Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency) (FEMA) to determine the effect of a storm and the likely scale of assistance required for disaster recovery.

If you are wondering, how bad the riots are and how they will affect the markets, using the Waffle House index, we determine that they aren't that bad and very quick recovery.

You can see the Waffle House index [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6RixCKRUbk)

author: campelm
body:
So I've begun pulling some money back out.  I agree that the recovery was too quick.  It was salvageable and possible for a V but I see political will to stay the course buckling.  We will open too quickly.  

People already won't take precaution now.  Once things open a percentage of people will treat it as free and clear.  The other will be buckling down and changing habits. This means less spending and probably a new round isolation.

But maybe I'm wrong and we isolate longer.  In that scenario I think we stay isolated longer than people investing are thinking and results won't match expectations 

But what if I'm wrong about both assumptions, you scoff? Well the funds I sold were off about 12% from ATH. If we hit/exceed that in thr short term I'll eat that loss as I still couldn't trust thst rally until we have good testing, treatment and/or vaccine.

In my risk/reward calculations, a calculated withdraw from this market seems like it's worth it for me

author: raltyinferno
body:
The wheel is a great theta gang strat.

1: Sell a cash covered put on a stock you'd like to own, at a strike you'd be willing to buy it at. Collect your premium

* If the price stays flat or goes up, keep your nice premium and sell another put.
* If the price drops below your strike, you get assigned and now own the stock.

2: Sell a covered call at a higher strike at a strike that puts you above your basis

* If the Stock stays flat or goes down, keep your premium and sell another call
* if the stock goes up, get your shares called away and use the money you got from it as collateral to sell another put and go back to step 1.

It's a good strategy because during no step can you actually lose money (on options). The only risk comes while holding the stock if it tanks, but then thats a risk with just holding stock in any case. You can also miss out on potential gains by having your shares called away if the stock jumps, but still, that's not losing money.

Example:

* SPY is at 300 today, you're willing to buy it for 295. You sell a 295p and collect a $5 premium, putting up $29,500 as collateral
* By expiration SPY is at 294, so you get assigned and buy the shares at $295 each.
* Your basis is 290 per share (put strike - premium collected) so you're willing to sell it at anything over that.
* You immediately sell a covered call 295c putting up your 100 shares for collateral for $5 premium
* By expiration Spy is at 296, so you get your shares called away, selling them for 295 each

you now have completed a full revolution of the wheel, and have made $100. Make sure you run it on a stock you feel fairly good about long term, because you are going to be buying and holding it during one step. If it crashes you're gonna be set back.

Here's the video I learned it from: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dRYBh6dtxjY

author: seattle_exile
body:
During the GFC, I went into a new Neiman Marcus in Seattle that had opened right as the collapse began. I was there with my wife to find some nice shoes for a funeral. The store was practically empty, and everything was, of course, super expensive.

When we went to check out, they informed me that they didn't take Visa - not even debit. Only American Express. I'd never heard of such a thing - even Costco allowed for debit. I didn't have an American Express card, so I asked them how they expected me to make a purchase. I can still see the sneer as the guy told me, "well, you could go to the ATM in the lobby."

I did not purchase the shoes, and I never set foot in a Neiman Marcus again.

Couldn't happen to a more deserving company.

author: BoiseBevo
body:
1. Q2 earnings.  Yes, everyone knows they'll be bad, but if 40% of shale drillers go under, and then 20% of retailers follow J Crew and Neiman Marcus going under, and then 2 of the Big 3 Auto guys need bailouts, and then real estate starts dropping due to unemployment and rent issues cascading, and then 1 of the too-big-to-fail banks needs a bailout...I'm not sure that's all priced in.
2. Dems and Repubs go back to not agreeing on anything, maybe coupled with deficit hawks remembering about the deficit again.  Powell's hands get tied in hopes of not running up the deficit, inducing a depression-level collapse when QE stops abruptly.
3. It becomes seen as patriotic in some circles not to wear a mask or socially distance such that Coronavirus cases skyrocket.  We'd be talking about "NY" levels of dead throughout vast swaths of the country.  It goes from 9/11 levels of dead Americans per day to 2-3 times that, and the media would be trying to decide if we might get Holocaust levels of dead overall, inducing Trump to blame China even more aggressively such that Xi cuts off export of things like masks to the US, shoots up Hong Kong, and craters the semiconductor industry, just to show who's boss...
4. Trump's poll numbers suffer so much he decides to shoot up some Iranian speed boats or bomb something in Venezuela or the South China Sea because Fox News flashes Bush poll numbers from the first Gulf War.  But of course it would be so horribly executed that Jared would be put in charge of fixing things...
5. Trump gets sick and dies (most likely not directly from Coronavirus but rather from the bleach enema someone endorsed at Mara Lago or some Chinese troll talked up on his twitter feed).  Things would definitely drop initially, but this might be the best hope for a V-shaped recovery.

Sorry for mixing in some politics, but I honestly think that a whole bunch of the downside stems from politics and reality clashing in ways that spill over into the market.  I can't ever remember a time it was easier to argue for what would have seemed like ridiculous worst-case scenarios just a couple years ago.

author: ts2981
body: Mnuchin warning unemployment is going to be >20%... slow rolling the bad news that there’s no V-shaped recovery here. At this point I’m programmed to think there’ll be no effect on the market. But it’s blowing my mind and sad that 1/5 ppl will have lost their jobs because some guy ate bat soup. What a fucking disaster. Also I’m starting to see some favorite stores and restaurants declare they’re going out of business. This sucks so much.

author: OrientalShamrock
body: Y’all got anymore of those V shaped recoveries?

body: All of that just to v-shape from 296 to 299 in 30 mins lmao. With futures pumps and intraday dip buying, this shit is never going down

author: karmalizing
body:
May 28th, Minneapolis

There was a riot in Target what the hell is this

You were sitting home on WSB

Trying to participate in some tendies

Buying calls on MGM and talkin' shit

I'm gonna buy a Cybertruck and never quit
